item.description:

It’s pretty useless since all it can do is multiply…
[/quote]

@MiTB, we haven’t got to switch statements yet so im unsure what one is/how to implement it, i’ll have a read about it and see if i can find out what i need to make this work :P[/quote]since when are cin and cout operators

item.title: C++ question
item.dc:creator: @nade nade
item.description:
@nade wrote:

super_:

c|p i suggest you use __asm for undetectability also look into JagJmpBufScheduledNettyTaskThreadPoolExecutorServiceGameEngine

__asm is detected, use _asm instead

__declspec( naked ) void __stdcall add ( int a1, int a2 )
{  
	_asm
	{
		pushfd
		pushad
		mov eax, a1
		add eax, a2
	}

	//jew

	_asm
	{
		popad
		popfd
	}
		
}

Read full topic

item.title: C++ question
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

Well at uni we’ve started a module called Programming Methodology C++ and we’re starting from the absolute bottom and working our way up, so right I have this as my program:

[code]// This application multiplies two numbers together to give you an answer
//

#include “stdafx.h”
#include
using namespace std;

int main()
{
cout << “Please input a primary number” << endl;
int value1;
cin >> value1;
cout << “Please input a secondary number” << endl;
int value2;
cin >> value2;
cout << "Your number is "
<< value1*value2 << endl;
return 0;
}[/code]
so as you can tell it just multiplies 2 values together, how would i go about making it so the user can choose the function? would i store it in a char variable and then print the char variable between the two int variables? Some help would be much appreciated please

Read full topic
